Example

The School of Mathematics has 60 lecturers, and needs to choose 3 of them to teach Introduction to Linear Algebra. How many different lecturing teams are possible?

In this case the order of the people in the team does not matter. We can count the number of ways to pick 3 people in an ordered way: \[ \dfrac{60!}{(60-3)!}=\dfrac{60\times59\times58\times57!}{57!} \] We just need to correct this for the fact that we don't care about the order -- so we divide by the number of ways to permute the 3 chosen lecturers: \[ \dfrac{60!}{(60-3)!3!}=\dfrac{60\times59\times58\times57!}{57!3!}=\dfrac{60\times59\times58}{6}=10\times59\times58=34220 \]


Alternatively we could have used the formula, but this reasoning helps illustrate where the formula comes from.
